{{Infobox stadium | logo_image = [[File:Investors Group Field logo.png|200px]] | image = [[File:Investors Group Field 2014.png|300px|Investors Group Field Winnipeg Manitoba]] | stadium_name = Investors Group Field | location = [[University of Manitoba]]
315 Chancellor-Matheson Road
[[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]] | broke_ground = May 20, 2010 | opened = May 26, 2013 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Triple B Stadium Inc. | operator = [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] | surface = [[FieldTurf]] Revolution{{cite web |title = Stadium Information |publisher = www.bluebombers.com |url = http://www.bluebombers.com/stadium-information|accessdate=2014-11-11}} | construction_cost = [[Canadian Dollar|$]]210 million | construction firm = Stuart Olson Dominion Construction | architect = Raymond S.C Wan | cost = $210 million{{cite news |title = Stadium dispute resolved, final price tag $210 million |publisher = Winnipeg Free Press|date = 2 May 2014 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/stadium-dispute-resolved-final-price-tag-210-million-257622631.html|accessdate=2014-06-01}} | tenants = [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] ([[Canadian Football League|CFL]]) (2013–present)
[[Manitoba Bisons]] ([[U Sports]]) (2013–present)
[[Winnipeg Rifles]] ([[Canadian Junior Football League|CJFL]]) (2013–present)
[[Valour FC]] ([[Canadian Premier League|CPL]]) (from 2019) | seating_capacity = 33,134 (expandable to 40,000)([[Canadian football|football]]) | suites = 46{{cite news |author = Brent Bellamy |title = The Jets – and a big-league stadium, too |publisher = Winnipeg Free Press|date = 10 October 2011 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/opinion/columnists/the-jets----and-a--big-league-stadium-too-131439343.html|accessdate=2014-06-01}} }} '''Investors Group Field''' is a football stadium in [[Winnipeg]], [[Manitoba]], Canada.{{cite news |title = Blue Bombers to get new stadium and new owner |publisher = TSN |url = https://www.tsn.ca/cfl/story/?id=273524|accessdate=2014-06-01}} The stadium, which opened in 2013, is located on the [[University of Manitoba]] campus next to [[University Stadium (Winnipeg)|University Stadium]].{{cite web|title=Winnipeg football stadium to be ready for 2012 season|url=http://www.journalofcommerce.com/article/id43587|publisher=Reed Business Information|accessdate=14 July 2013|author=Peter Caulfield|date=March 28, 2011|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130503073826/http://www.journalofcommerce.com/article/id43587|archive-date=3 May 2013|dead-url=yes|df=dmy-all}} Owned by Triple B Stadium Inc., a [[consortium]] of the City of Winnipeg, the Province of Manitoba, the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers|Winnipeg Football Club]] and the University of Manitoba,{{cite news |author = Sean Kavanagh |title = Lawsuit alleges Winnipeg's IGF stadium leaky, mouldy |publisher = CBC Manitoba|date = 5 March 2015 |url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/lawsuit-alleges-winnipeg-s-igf-stadium-leaky-mouldy-1.2983608|accessdate=2015-03-05}} the stadium is home to the [[Winnipeg Blue Bombers]] of the [[Canadian Football League]] (CFL), [[University of Manitoba Bisons]] [[U Sports football|football]] team, and the [[Winnipeg Rifles]] ([[CJFL]]). It will also be home to [[Valour FC]] of the [[Canadian Premier League]] beginning in 2019.{{Cite web|url=http://valourfc.canpl.ca/stadium-profile/|title=Stadium Profile|last=|first=|date=June 6, 2018|website=valourfc.canpl.ca|publisher=Valour FC|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=June 11, 2018}} The stadium has a capacity of 33,500 and is partially covered. The stadium contains a corrugated metal roof, restaurant, 52 suites, walk of fame and other amenities. ==History== ===Development=== The owners of [[Canad Inns]], a Winnipeg-based hotel business and naming rights holder for the [[Canad Inns Stadium|Blue Bombers' former stadium]], forwarded a plan in 2007 to redevelop the entire site for commercial use and construct a football stadium for the Blue Bombers in another location. This proposal, although rejected in favour of [[David Asper]]'s plan, called for a $265 million stadium at the former Public Markets site in the St. Boniface industrial park, which Canad Inns purchased from the city. The domed stadium would have been part of a $500 million complex that would have included a four-star hotel and an indoor water park.{{cite news |title = Canad Inns proposes domed stadium for Winnipeg |publisher = CBC News|date = 10 April 2007 |url = http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/canad-inns-proposes-domed-stadium-for-winnipeg-1.642575|accessdate=2014-06-01}} David Asper's original proposal involved both [[Government of Canada|federal]] and [[Government of Manitoba|provincial]] government financial contributions ($40 million each), as well as a transfer of assets (the publicly owned Blue Bomber franchise itself will be transferred into Asper's control, and the existing undeveloped commercial real estate surrounding the stadium). As part of Creswin's commitment to the project, Asper pledged to contribute $65 million toward the Maroons Road development. In addition to stadium construction, the Asper proposal included {{convert|217000|sqft|m2|abbr=on}} of retail development and a two-level parking facility. The Blue Bombers' board of directors investigated the possibility of rebuilding or substantially upgrading the existing stadium, largely with funds generated from the sale or lease of the adjacent commercial lands{{cite web|url=http://www.mcgowanrussell.com/projects/wbb.php|title=McGowan Russell Group|website=Mcgowanrussell.com|accessdate=9 September 2017}} (the team holds the right to develop this property itself as part of its refinancing agreement with the city of Winnipeg and province of Manitoba). However, being a community owned business, the Bombers organization would have had difficulty in accessing the capital required to move forward with such plans directly. The board placed its plans on hold pending the outcome of Asper's proposal. The government was unwilling to grant Asper the $40 million at both the provincial and federal levels because it believed the money to be more of a gift than a grant. Creswin drew up a second proposal, where the same 30,000–40,000-seat stadium would be built instead in south Point Douglas.{{cite news |title = Asper unveils new stadium vision |publisher = [[Winnipeg Free Press]] |date = 27 June 2008 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/historic/32918854.html |accessdate=2014-06-01}} This new plan, they said, would greatly aid in urban renewal in what is the poorest neighborhood in Winnipeg. There was also a state-of-the-art water park and hotel, commercial buildings and several other new buildings in the multimillion-dollar proposal. However, there was controversy as well because south Point Douglas is an avid art community, and many of the residents did not want their character buildings to be destroyed or suffer the loss of their homes.{{cite news |author = Gary Lawless |title = Selinger grabs ball on stadium |publisher = [[Winnipeg Free Press]] |date = 27 March 2010 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/selinger-grabs-ball-on-stadium-89319412.html |accessdate=2010-04-07}} [[File:Winnipeg Nov 2 2013 Max Hall.JPG|thumb|left|An in-game photo of the Winnipeg Blue Bombers on offence against the [[Hamilton Tiger-Cats]].]] A letter of intent was signed on September 13, 2009, between Asper's Creswin Properties and the University of Manitoba, allowing planning to continue for a stadium at the intersection of Chancellor Matheson Drive and University Crescent. The site is adjacent to the current [[University Stadium (Winnipeg)|University Stadium]], which was built for the 1967 Pan American Games. The new proposal includes the construction of a 33,422-seat stadium, renovation of the existing stadium, and a world-class fitness facility. Inflatable "bubbles" covering the playing field will also be made available in both stadiums during the winter months. The cost of the new stadium, was projected to be $115 million.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/bombers-stadium-costs-climb-higher-1.894278|title=Bombers stadium costs climb higher|website=Cbc.ca|accessdate=9 September 2017}} The new stadium would also be home of the [[University of Manitoba Bisons]] football team. The design allows for expansion to 40,000 seats for the [[Grey Cup]] (however for [[2015 Grey Cup]] 36,500 seats were available). The stadium was approved on 2 April 2009. The province of Manitoba later agreed to loan David Asper $90 million in order to guarantee the project would break ground in 2010 and ensure the stadium would open for 2012.{{cite news|author=Bartley Kives |title=Manitoba gives $90M loan for new Bombers stadium |publisher=[[National Post]] |date=31 March 2010 |url=http://www.nationalpost.com/sports/story.html?id=2748771 |accessdate=2010-04-07 }}{{dead link|date=September 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}{{cite news |author = Ed Tait |title = Sod turns on new stadium |publisher = [[Winnipeg Free Press]] |date =20 May 2010 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/sod-turns-on-new-stadium-94403949.html |accessdate=2010-05-20}} CFL Commissioner [[Mark Cohon]], Premier of Manitoba [[Greg Selinger]], David Asper, Mayor of Winnipeg [[Sam Katz]] and U of M President David Barnard officially broke ground at the site on May 20, 2010. [[File:Investors Group CANnwt vs USnwt.png|thumb|right|200px|The Canada vs USA women's soccer game exhibition played in May, 2014 to a 1–1 draw.]] Asper and Creswin were removed from the deal as they made significant changes to the stadium design which broke the original contract.{{cite news| url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/football/story/2010/12/13/mb-stadium-financing-details-bombers-winnipeg.html |title=Asper out of Blue Bomber stadium plans|date=December 13, 2010|publisher=[[CBC Sports]]|accessdate=2014-06-01}} The revised cost amounted to $190 million, with the Winnipeg Blue Bombers paying back $85 million, and the provincial and city levels of government splitting the rest of the costs as previously proposed. ===Controversy=== The new stadium was expected to be ready for the start of the 2012 season.{{cite news|author = Ross Romaniuk | url=http://www.winnipegsun.com/2011/08/26/blue-bombers-stadium-taking-shape |title= Blue Bombers stadium taking shape |date= 2011-09-07 |publisher=[[Winnipeg Sun]]|accessdate=2014-06-01}} However, on May 2, 2012, the Blue Bombers announced that because of constructions delays, the stadium would not be ready until September, thus forcing the team to play four or five home games at [[Canad Inns Stadium]] to start the season.{{cite news |author = Gary Lawless and Bruce Owen |title = First game in new stadium could be as early as Sept. 9: Bombers |publisher = Winnipeg Free Press|date = 25 May 2012 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/First-game-in-new-stadium-to-be-Sept-21-Bombers-149833095.html|accessdate=2014-06-01}} In June 2012, it was announced the stadium would not open until the 2013 season.{{cite news|title=Bombers to play entire season at Canad Inns Stadium |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/football/bombers/159204945.html |publisher=''Winnipeg Free Press |date=June 15, 2012}} In December 2013, it was reported the previously-announced inflatable dome had been dropped from the plans in 2012.{{cite news | author = Bartley Kives | title = Winter stadium bubble deemed impractical |publisher = [[Winnipeg Free Press]] |date =6 December 2013 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/breakingnews/Winter-stadium-bubble-deemed-impractical-234803401.html |accessdate=2014-06-01}} In 2014, the builder, Stuart Olson Dominion, put a $1.9 million lien on the stadium because it claimed it was owed for some of the cost overruns.{{cite news |author = Bartley Kives |title = Construction firm slaps lien on stadium |publisher = Winnipeg Free Press|date = 10 January 2014 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/construction-firm-slaps-lien-on-stadium-239548191.html|accessdate=2014-06-01}} This dispute was resolved later that year, with the province contributing an additional $1.5 million to cover additional costs incurred during construction, bringing the total cost to $210 million. On March 4, 2015, the stadium's ownership group, Triple B Stadium Inc., announced its intention to sue architect Ray Wan and builder Stuart Olson Dominion.{{cite news |author = Bartley Kives |title = Stadium owner to sue architect, builder over water drainage, insulation problems |publisher = Winnipeg Free Press|date = 4 March 2015 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/football/bombers/295009101.html|accessdate=2015-03-05}} In the statement of claim, it cited water damage caused by insufficient drainage in the building, as well as inadequate insulation and "extensive" cracking in the concrete among a total of 42 deficiencies. On April 23, Stuart Olson filed a statement of defence denying most of Triple B's allegations, stating the shell company — which represents the city, province, university and the Winnipeg Football Club — made all the key construction decisions, in concert with the province, which paid for most of the construction up front. Stuart Olson also alleged political and financial factors led the province to rush the job and reduce its budget.{{cite web|url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/football/bombers/Strife-over-Investors-Group-Field-is-hurting-the-Bombers-303945721.html|title=Strife over Investors Group Field is hurting the Bombers|website=Winnipegfreepress.com|accessdate=9 September 2017}} On October 27, 2015, the government of Manitoba announced it would pay $35 million to repair the stadium. It would then seek compensation for this further outlay of money from the proceeds of the aforementioned lawsuit.{{cite web|url=http://www.cbc.ca/news/canada/manitoba/premier-greg-selinger-defends-35m-loan-guarantee-to-fix-investors-group-field-1.3291117|title=Premier Greg Selinger defends $35M loan guarantee to fix Investors Group Field|website=Cbc.ca|accessdate=9 September 2017}} ==Notable events== ===Football=== The Blue Bombers played their first home game at Investors Group Field on June 27, 2013, losing 38–33 to the [[Montreal Alouettes]].{{cite news|title=CFL releases 2013 regular season schedule | url=http://www.cbc.ca/sports/football/cfl/story/2013/03/05/sp-cfl-season-schedule-2013.html|publisher=CBC|date=March 5, 2013 | accessdate = 2014-06-01}}{{cite news |author = Paul Wiecek |title = Bombers late to the party |publisher = Winnipeg Free Press|date = 28 June 2013 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/football/bombers/bombers-late-to-the-party-213464451.html|accessdate=2014-06-01}} In March 2014, it was confirmed that Investors Group Field would host the [[103rd Grey Cup|2015 Grey Cup]].{{cite news |author = Judy Owen |title = CFL to show off Investors Group Field as Winnipeg picked to host 2015 Grey Cup |publisher = Winnipeg Free Press|date = 26 March 2014 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/football/cfl/cfl-to-show-off-investors-group-field-as-winnipeg-picked-to-host-2015-grey-cup-252491901.html|accessdate=2014-06-01}} ===Hockey=== Investors Group Field hosted the fourth instalment of the [[National Hockey League]] (NHL)'s [[2016 Heritage Classic|Heritage Classic]] on October 23, 2016, in which the [[Winnipeg Jets]] lost 3–0 to the [[Edmonton Oilers]] in front of a sold-out crowd. The Classic's customary alumni game was played a day earlier and featured players from [[Winnipeg Jets (1972–96)|the former Jets franchise]] returning to Winnipeg to play the Oilers alumni team. The Jets alumni, led by [[Teemu Selänne]] and [[Dale Hawerchuk]], defeated [[Wayne Gretzky]]'s Oilers squad 6–5 in a shootout.{{cite news|url=https://globalnews.ca/news/3020054/winnipeg-jets-beat-edmonton-oilers-6-5-at-heritage-classic-alumni-game/|title=Winnipeg Jets beat Edmonton Oilers 6-5 at Heritage Classic alumni game|date=October 22, 2016|publisher=GlobalNews.ca}} ===Soccer=== The [[Canada women's national soccer team]] played their first match at Investors Group Field on May 8, 2014, against the [[United States women's national soccer team|United States]], with the result in a tie (1–1); this match was the stadium's first soccer game.{{cite news |title=World's best can't beat Canada |author=Ed Tait |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/soccer/worlds-best-cant-beat-canada-258585901.html |publisher=''[[Winnipeg Free Press]]'' |date=May 9, 2014}} In June 2015, Winnipeg was one of six Canadian cities that hosted the [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup|FIFA Women's World Cup]]. The first four matches of [[2015 FIFA Women's World Cup Group D|Group D]]—between the United States, [[Australia women's national soccer team|Australia]], [[Sweden women's national football team|Sweden]] and [[Nigeria women's national football team|Nigeria]]—were contested at Investors Group Field, followed by three matches from various other groups.{{cite news |author = Ed Tait |title = Winnipeg to host FIFA Women's World Cup |publisher = [[Winnipeg Free Press]] |date =5 May 2012 |url = http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/sports/soccer/Winnipeg-to-host-FIFA-Womens-World-Cup-150207165.html | accessdate = 2012-05-04}} Due to [[FIFA]]'s policy regarding commercial sponsorship of stadium names, the Investors Group Field was referred to as "Winnipeg Stadium" during the World Cup.{{cite web|url=https://www.fifa.com/womensworldcup/destination/cities/city=18908/index.html |title=FIFA Women's World Cup Canada 2015™ Destination: Winnipeg |publisher=FIFA |accessdate=4 January 2015}} '''2015 FIFA Women's World Cup''' {{clear}} {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:left; width:85%;" |- !Date !Time ([[Central Daylight Time|CDT]]) !Team #1 !Result !Team #2 !Round !Attendance |- |style="text-align:center;" rowspan=2|8 June 2015||style="text-align:center;"| 15:00||{{fbw|SWE}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 3–3 ||{{fbw|NGA}} ||rowspan=4|Group D ||style="text-align:center;"|31,148 |- |style="text-align:center;"|18:30||{{fbw|USA}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 3–1 ||{{fbw|AUS}} ||style="text-align:center;"|31,148 |- |style="text-align:center;" rowspan=2|12 June 2015||style="text-align:center;"| 16:00||{{fbw|AUS}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 2–0 ||{{fbw|NGA}} ||style="text-align:center;"|32,716 |- |style="text-align:center;"|19:00||{{fbw|USA}} ||style="text-align:center;"|0–0||{{fbw|SWE}} ||style="text-align:center;"|32,716 |- |style="text-align:center;" rowspan=2|15 June 2015||style="text-align:center;"| 15:00||{{fbw|GER}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 4–0 ||{{fbw|THA}} ||Group B ||style="text-align:center;"|26,191 |- |style="text-align:center;"| 18:30||{{fbw|CHN}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 2–2 ||{{fbw|NZL}} ||Group A ||style="text-align:center;"|26,191 |- |style="text-align:center;" |16 June 2015||style="text-align:center;"| 16:00||{{fbw|ECU}} ||style="text-align:center;"| 0–1 ||{{fbw|JPN}} ||Group C ||style="text-align:center;"|14,522 |- |} ===Concerts=== {| class="wikitable" style="text-align:center;" |- ! width=12% style="text-align:center; Tour]] || 30,741 / 30,741 || $3,008,250 || A cover of [[Black Hole Sun]] by [[Soundgarden]] was performed as a tribute to [[Chris Cornell]] |} ===Other events=== The stadium hosted its first event on May 26, 2013, with the One Heart Winnipeg celebration, a multi-denominational church service organized by several local church groups.{{cite news |title=Church service a first look at Bombers' new digs |author=Alexandra Hall |url=http://www.winnipegfreepress.com/local/stadium-a-blessing-209039261.html |publisher=[[Winnipeg Free Press]] |date=May 27, 2013 | accessdate = 2014-06-01}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== {{commons category}} * {{official website|http://www.bluebombers.com/stadium}} {{s-start-collapsible|header={{s-sta|et}}}} {{succession box | title = Home of the

Jamie "Showtime" Stafford | country = United States | network = [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] | first_aired = January 10, 2000 | last_aired = | director = [[John Sacret Young]] | producer = [[Stephanie Germain]]
Tom Patricia
[[George W. Perkins (television producer)|George W. Perkins]]
[[John Sacret Young]] | music = [[John Frizzell]] | distributor = | runtime = 120 minutes | language = English | budget = |}} '''''King of the World''''' is an American [[television film]] which aired on January 10, 2000 on [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]]. It chronicles the early stages of the career of [[heavyweight]] [[boxing|boxer]] [[Muhammad Ali]] (then known as Cassius Clay), who is portrayed by [[Terrence Howard]]. It is based upon a [[King of the World (Book)|biography]] of the same name by [[David Remnick]].{{cite news | author = Hal Erickson | title = Muhammad Ali: King of the World (2000) | url = https://movies.nytimes.com/movie/273218/Muhammad-Ali-King-of-the-World/overview | format = | work = NYTimes.com | date = }} ==Cast and crew== *[[File:Terrance Howard with Cast Member Sam Olivares.jpg|thumb|Sam Olivares with Terrence Howard.]][[Terrence Howard]] - [[Muhammad Ali|Cassius Clay]]The events of this film occur before the boxer assumed the name Muhammad Ali. Thus, he is only referred to by his birth name, Cassius Clay. *[[Steve Harris (actor)|Steve Harris]] - [[Sonny Liston]] *[[Chi McBride]] - [[Drew Bundini Brown]] *[[Gary Dourdan]] - [[Malcolm X]] *[[John Ventimiglia]] - [[Angelo Dundee]] *Jamie "Showtime" Stafford - Young Cassius Clay ==Plot summary== Having won the [[gold medal]] for [[boxing]] in the [[light heavyweight]] division at the [[1960 Summer Olympics]] in [[Rome]], [[Kentucky]] native [[Muhammad Ali|Cassius Clay]] ([[Terrence Howard]]) challenges professional [[heavyweight]] boxing champion [[Sonny Liston]] ([[Steve Harris (actor)|Steve Harris]]) for the title. The media is both intrigued and repulsed by his brash manner and what appears to be self-worship. Despite being a heavy [[underdog (competition)|underdog]], the 22-year-old Clay shocks the sports world by defeating Liston by [[technical knockout]] in their [[Muhammad Ali vs. Sonny Liston|February 1964 bout]], becoming heavyweight champion and (metaphorically) "king of the world". ==DVD== Although it is an American film, ''King of the World'' was released on DVD in [[DVD region code#2|Region 2]] format, which is used predominately in [[Europe]]. It has yet to be released in Region 1 format, which is compatible with DVD players used in the [[United States]] and [[Canada]]. ==References== {{reflist}} == External links == * {{IMDb title|0219857|King of the World}} {{Muhammad Ali Footer}} {{John Sacret Young}} [[Category:Films about Muhammad Ali]] [[Category:2000 television films]] [[Category:American drama films]] [[Category:American television films]] [[Category:American biographical films]] [[Category:American films]] [[Category:African-American films]] [[Category:Boxing films]] [[Category:Films set in the 1960s]] [[Category:Films based on actual events]] [[Category:Films shot in Houston]] [[Category:Sports films based on actual events]] [[Category:English-language films]] [[Category:2000s drama films]] [[Category:2000s sports films]] {{US-tv-drama-film-stub}} {{bio-film-stub}}

page.title: List of foreign Primeira Liga players

revision.text:
{{short description|Wikimedia list article}} {{Multiple issues| {{Refimprove|date=July 2017}} {{More footnotes|date=July 2017}} }} {{inc-sport}}
This is a list of foreign players that have played in the Portuguese [[Primeira Liga]].
Players in '''bold''' are the ones that have international caps for their senior national team. Clubs in '''bold''' are the current clubs of those players.

revision.text:
{{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Midland Bank Sports Ground | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | image = File:Midland bank.jpg | caption = The pavilion at the former Midland Bank Sports Ground | country = England | location = [[Beckenham]], [[London Borough of Bromley]] | coordinates = {{coord|51.418|N|0.038|W|type:landmark|display=title, inline}} | establishment = 1930 | demolished = | last used = | seating_capacity = | owner = [[HSBC]] | architect = | contractor = | operator = | tenants = | home club = HSBC Cricket Club | county club = | end1 = | end2 = | year1 = 1970 | club1 = [[Kent County Cricket Club]] | year2 = 1983–present | club2 = HSBC Cricket Club | date = 10 August | year = 2016 | source = https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/308.html CricketArchive }} '''Midland Bank Sports Ground''' is a sports ground in [[Beckenham]] in the [[London Borough of Bromley]]. The ground is owned by [[HSBC]] bank and is now known as the '''HSBC Sports and Social Club'''. The ground was used for one First XI [[cricket]] match by [[Kent County Cricket Club]] and hosted one match in the [[1993 Women's Cricket World Cup]].
It is located around {{convert|0.75|mi|km}} north-west of Beckenham town centre on Lennard Road. The [[Mid-Kent line|Mid-Kent railway line]] runs along the eastern edge of the ground with [[New Beckenham railway station]] adjacent to the south-east corner. The [[River Pool (London)|River Pool]] runs along the western edge the ground.<ref name=osx161>Explorer Map 161 – London South (Westminster, Greenwich, Croydon, Esher & Twickenham), [[Ordnance Survey]], 2015-09-16.</ref>
==Cricketing history== The ground was established in 1920 by the London Joint City and Midland Bank Sports Association, an organisation which dated back to 1871 and became the Midland Bank Sports association in 1923.<ref name=milton>Milton H (1979) Kent cricket grounds, in ''The Cricket Statistician'', no. 28, December 1979, pp.2–10.</ref> The first recorded cricket match on the ground was in 1930 when the Club Cricket Conference played the [[Universities Athletic Union]].<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/308_misc.html Other matches played on Midland Bank Sports Ground], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2016-08-11.</ref>
The ground hosted a single [[List-A cricket]] match when [[Kent County Cricket Club]] beat [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] in a rain affected match in the [[1970 John Player League]].<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/308_a.html List-A Matches played on Midland Bank Sports Ground], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2016-08-11.</ref> The ground was used as part of the centenary celebrations of the Midland Bank Sports association.<ref name=milton /> The match saw Kent win by scoring more runs in the first nine overs of their innings than Lancashire had scored in their first ten overs, scoring 58 for 1 wicket. The result attracted some controversy because technically Kent had to bat for 10 overs before able to claim a win.<ref name=times30nov70>Woodcock J (1970) Kent win sprint but Lancashire may appeal, ''[[The Times]]'', 1970-05-11, p.6. Times Digital Archive. Retrieved 2017-11-30.</ref>
Beckenham was part of [[Kent]] until 1965 and the county has played matches at a number of grounds in what it describes as "Metropolitan Kent".<ref name=guide3jun16>Clifford J (2016) 'Welcome to the Kent County Ground, Beckenham' in ''Match Guide'', 2016-06-03. Canterbury: [[Kent County Cricket Club]].</ref><ref name=17annual210>Grounds Records in ''Kent County Cricket Club Annual 2017'', pp.210–211. Canterbury: [[Kent County Cricket Club]].</ref> It maintains a current base at the [[Kent County Cricket Ground, Beckenham]] {{convert|0.5|mi|km}} from the ground.
During the [[1993 Women's Cricket World Cup]] the ground held a single [[Women's One Day International cricket|Women's One Day International]] when [[Australia women's cricket team|Australia women]] were beaten by [[New Zealand women's cricket team|New Zealand women]].<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/308_wo.html Women's One-Day International Matches played on Midland Bank Sports Ground], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2016-08-11.</ref> [[Debbie Hockley]], who top-scored with 38 not out, and [[Penny Kinsella]] passed the Australian total of 77 without losing a wicket. [[Julie Harris (cricketer)|Julie Harris]] took 3 wickets for 15 runs from nine overs for New Zealand as they knocked the favourites Australia out of the tournament in the final series of round-robin matches.<ref name=cw>Grummittt D (2013) [http://www.cricketworld.com/women-s-world-cup-history-england-1993/33301.htm Women's World Cup History - England 1993], ''Cricket World'', 2013-01-28. Retrieved 2016-08-11.</ref><ref name=card93>[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/57/57678.html Australia women v New Zealand women - scorecard], CricketArchive. Retrieved 2016-08-11.</ref>
==Modern use== In local cricket, the ground is the home venue of [[HSBC Cricket Club]]<ref>[http://hsbc.play-cricket.com/home/home.asp HSBC Cricket Club] {{webarchive|url=https://archive.is/20120718224429/http://hsbc.play-cricket.com/home/home.asp |date=2012-07-18 }}. Retrieved 2016-08-11.</ref> who play in the [[Kent Cricket League]]. This site includes three cricket pitches as well as a number of net areas. As well as cricket, a number of other sports are played at the ground, including [[field hockey|hockey]], [[association football|football]], tennis and squash.<ref name=hsbcccfacilities>[http://hsbc.play-cricket.com/website/web_pages/183774 About us], HSBC Cricket Club. Retrieved 2016-08-11.</ref> An astroturf pitch is used by New Beccehamian Hockey Club.<ref name=nbhc>[http://www.newbeccshc.co.uk/location Location], New Beccehamian Hockey Club. Retrieved 2016-08-11.</ref>
==See also== *[[List of Kent County Cricket Club grounds]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.cricinfo.com/england/content/ground/56778.html Midland Bank Sports Ground] at [[CricInfo]]
{{Kent CCC}}

revision.text:
{{hatnote|See [[Korisliiga]] for men's top [[basketball]] league in [[Finland]].}} {{Infobox sports league | title = Naisten Korisliiga | current_season = | logo = | pixels = | caption = | sport = [[Basketball]] | founded = 1944 | formerly = Naisten SM-sarja
(Women's Finnish Championship) | inaugural = | teams = [[#Current teams|10]] | country = {{flagicon|Finland}} [[Finland]] | continent = {{flagicon|EUR}} [[FIBA Europe]] ([[Europe]]) | folded = | most_champs = [[Forssan Alku]], [[Sampo Basket]], [[Tampereen Pyrintö (basketball)|Tampereen Pyrintö]], [[Nokian Urheilijat]]
(8 titles) | TV = [[YLE TV2]] | champion = [[Catz Lappeenranta]]
(4th title) | levels = | relegation = [[Naisten I Divisioona]] | domestic_cup = | website = [http://korisliiga.fi/naiset/en Korisliiga.fi] }} '''Naisten Korisliiga''' ([[English language|English]]: ''Women's Basketball League'') is the highest tier of women's basketball in [[Finland]]. The competition was formerly known as Naisten SM-sarja ([[English language|English]]: ''Women's Finnish Championship'') and was renamed to Naisten Korisliiga for the 2013-14 season. ==History== Women's Finnish Championship was first introduced in 1944. The first championship was won by [[Helsingin Tarmo]]. In the 1940s, the league had six teams and the title was awarded after the regular season. In 1953 the number of teams was raised to ten. Postseason [[playoffs]] were first played in the 1973-74 season, with [[Nokian Urheilijat]] emerging victorious after defeating first [[Tapiolan Honka]] (2-1) in the Semifinals and then [[Työväen Mailapojat]] (2-1) in the Finals.{{cite web |url=http://www.basket.fi/english/competitions/history/?league_id=1&season_id=89397 |title= Naisten Korisliiga History |website= Basket.fi |publisher= Finnish Basketball Association | accessdate= 3 November 2014}} For the 2014-15 season, the league has 10 teams and each team plays each other three times in the regular season, resulting in 27 games per team. The top 8 teams continue to postseason playoffs which are played in [[Playoff format#Best-of-five playoff|Best-of-five]] format. The team placed last after the regular season is relegated to [[Naisten I Divisioona]] ([[English language|English]]: ''Women's First Division'').{{cite web |url=http://www.basket.fi/asiakaspalvelu/koriksen_abc/saannot/ |title= Naisten Korisliiga Rules & Regulations |website= Basket.fi |publisher= Finnish Basketball Association | accessdate= 4 November 2014|language=fi}} [[Lea Hakala]] could be seen as the most influential player so far in the history of Naisten Korisliiga. Hakala played 25 seasons in the league and currently leads the record for career points. She has won the championship title for record-breaking 15 times and she has also been awarded the Player of the Year Award for 4 times.{{cite web|title=Lea Hakala|url=http://www.basket.fi/sarjat/pelaajat/pelaaja/?season_id=26&player_id=53986&league_id=1|website=Basket.fi|publisher=Finnish Basketball Association|accessdate=10 November 2014}} ==Current teams== [[File:Catz - 2009-2010 Finnish Champions.jpg|400px|thumbnail|right|[[Catz Lappeenranta]] celebrating their 2009-10 season championship title.]] * [[Catz Lappeenranta]], [[Lappeenranta]] * [[Forssan Alku]], [[Forssa]] * [[Hyvinkään Ponteva]], [[Hyvinkää]] * [[Peli-Karhut]], [[Kotka]] * [[Tampereen Pyrintö (basketball)|Tampereen Pyrintö]], [[Tampere]] * [[Tapiolan Honka]], [[Espoo]] * [[Torpan Pojat]], [[Helsinki]] * [[Turun Riento]], [[Turku]] * [[Vimpelin Veto]], [[Vimpeli]] * [[Äänekosken Huima]], [[Äänekoski]] ==Recent champions== {| class="wikitable" ! revision.text:
{{infobox country at games | NPC = NIG | NPCname = Fédération Nigérienne des Sports Paralympiques | games = Paralympics | year = | flagcaption = | oldcode = | website = | location = | competitors = | sports = | flagbearer = | rank = | gold = 0 | silver = 0 | bronze = 0 | officials = | appearances = | app_begin_year = | app_end_year = | summerappearances = {{Team appearances list|team=Niger|competition=Summer Paralympics|begin_year=2004|end_year= }} | winterappearances = | seealso = }} '''[[Niger]]''' made its [[Paralympic Games]] début at the [[2004 Summer Paralympics]] in [[Athens]]. It was represented by a single athlete, male sprinter [[Zoubeirou Issaka]], who competed in the 100m race, in the T12 category for the nearly blind. His time of 13.90 was the slowest overall in the heats, ending his participation in the Games.[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=NIG&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Niger at the Paralympics], [[International Paralympic Committee]] In [[2008 Summer Paralympics|2008]], Niger was represented only by male [[powerlifting|powerlifter]] [[Zakari Amadou]], in the up to 67.5 kg category. He lifted 110 kg, ranking 13th and last of those who successfully lifted a weight.[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=NIG&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Niger at the Paralympics], International Paralympic Committee Niger has never taken part in the [[Winter Paralympics]].[http://www.paralympic.org/Sport/Results/search.html?npc=NIG&gender=all&medal=all&sport=all&games=all Niger at the Paralympics], International Paralympic Committee Niger will be taking part in the [[2012 Summer Paralympics]], and the [[Fédération Nigérienne des Sports Paralympiques]] have chosen [[Bedford]] as the UK training base for its Paralympians.{{cite web |url=http://www.bedford.gov.uk/council_and_democracy/council_news/archived_news/february_2012/on_your_marks.aspx |title=Archived copy |accessdate=2012-08-06 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120714070430/http://www.bedford.gov.uk/council_and_democracy/council_news/archived_news/february_2012/on_your_marks.aspx |archivedate=2012-07-14 |df= }} ==Full results for Niger at the Paralympics== {| class="wikitable sortable" style="font-size:90%" |- !Name !Games !Sport !Event !Score !Rank |- | [[Zoubeirou Issaka]] || [[2004 Summer Paralympics|2004 Athens]] || [[Athletics at the 2004 Summer Paralympics|Athletics]] || Men's 100m T12 || 13.90 || 4th in heat 5;
did not advance |- | [[Zakari Amadou]] || [[2008 Summer Paralympics|2008 Beijing]] || [[Powerlifting at the 2008 Summer Paralympics|Powerlifting]] || Men's Up To 67.5 kg || 110 kg || 13th |} ==See also== * [[Niger at the Olympics]] ==References== {{Reflist}} {{Nations at the Paralympics}} [[Category:Niger at the Paralympics| ]] {{Niger-sport-stub}} {{Paralympics-stub}}

{{Infobox gymnast |name= Sara Raposeiro |gender= w |image= |image_size= |caption= |fullname= |altname= |nickname= |country= {{flagu|Portugal}} |regions= |formercountry= |birth_date= {{birth date and age|1999|3|9|df=y}} |birth_place= |hometown= |residence= |death_date= |death_place= |height= |discipline= WAG |level= Senior International Elite
([[Portugal women's national gymnastics team|Portugal national team]]) |natlteam= 2015 |club= |gym= |collegeteam= |headcoach= |assistcoach= |formercoach= |choreographer= |music= |eponymousskills= |retired= |worldranking= |updated= |show-medals= yes |medaltemplates= }} '''Sara Raposeiro''' (born {{birth date|1999|3|9|df=yes}}) is a Portuguese female [[artistic gymnast]], representing her nation at international competitions. She competed at the [[2014 Summer Youth Olympics]], and at world championships, including the [[2015 World Artistic Gymnastics Championships]] in Glasgow.{{cite web|title=2015 World Gymnastics Championships athletes - Sara Raposeiro|url= http://gym.longinestiming.com/File/00000E00010001FFFFFFFFFFFFFFFF00 |work=longinestiming.com|date= |accessdate=27 January 2016}} ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{cite web|url=https://database.fig-gymnastics.com/public/gymnasts/biography/23308/true?backUrl=%2Fpublic%2Fresults%2Fdisplay%2F5763%3FidAgeCategory%3D5%26idCategory%3D66%23anchor_29240 |title=Raposeiro Sara |website=Database.fig-gymnastics.com |date= |accessdate=2017-03-07}} *{{cite web|url=https://thegymter.net/sara-raposeiro/ |title=Sara Raposeiro | The Gymternet |website=Thegymter.net |date=1999-03-09 |accessdate=2017-03-07}} *{{cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=M7pOWYmkjs0 |title=Sara Raposeiro POR - Floor Music 2015 |publisher=[[YouTube]] |date=2015-12-18 |accessdate=2017-03-07}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Raposeiro, Sara}} [[Category:1999 births]] [[Category:Living people]] [[Category:Portuguese female artistic gymnasts]] [[Category:Place of birth missing (living people)]] [[Category:Gymnasts at the 2014 Summer Youth Olympics]] {{Portugal-sport-stub}} {{Portugal-bio-stub}}

{{Infobox football club | clubname = Sharikat Naft Al-Basra| image = Sharikat Naft Al-Basra logo.png | image_size = 200 | fullname = Sharikat Naft Al-Basra | nickname = | founded = | ground = | capacity = | chairman = | manager = | league = | | season = {{plainlist| *Final season *[[1949 Iraq FA Championship|1949]]}} | position =
Iraq FA Championship, 1st }} '''Sharikat Naft Al-Basra''' ({{lang-ar|'''فريق شركة نفط البصرة'''|lit=''Basra Oil Company''}}), was an [[Iraq]]i football team based in [[Basra]]. They became Iraq's first ever official national champions when they won the one-off [[1949 Iraq FA Championship]] that was played between teams from across the country rather than from a specific province or region like other Iraqi competitions before 1974.[http://www.rsssf.com/tablesi/iraq49.html Iraq 1948/49] The team no longer exists. ==Honours== *'''[[1949 Iraq FA Championship|Iraq FA Championship]]''' **'''Winner (1):''' [[1948–49 Iraq FA Championship|1949]] ==Notable Players== * [[Saeed Easho]] * [[Shaker Ismail]] ==References== {{reflist}} [[Category:Football clubs in Iraq]] {{Iraq-footyclub-stub}}

[[Philipp Lothar Mayring]]
[[Fritz Rotter]]
[[Fritz Zeckendorf]] | narrator = | starring = [[Heinz Rühmann]]
[[Toni van Eyck]]

[[Erno Hajos]] | studio = [[Universum Film AG|UFA]] | distributor = UFA | released = 25 October 1932 | runtime = 99 minutes | country = Germany | language = [[German language|German]] | budget = | gross = | website = }} '''''Spoiling the Game''''' (German: '''''Strich durch die Rechnung''''') is a 1932 German [[comedy film]] directed by [[Alfred Zeisler]] and starring [[Heinz Rühmann]], [[Toni van Eyck]] and [[Hermann Speelmans]].Wadlman p.46 Its hero is a young [[cyclist]] who enters a race. It was made by German's largest film company [[Universum Film AG|UFA]]. The film's sets were designed by the [[art director]]s [[Willi Herrmann]] and [[Herbert Lippschitz]]. A separate French-language version ''{{Interlanguage link multi|Rivaux de la piste|fr}}'' was also released. ==Cast== * [[ Heinz Rühmann]] as Willy Streblow - Rennfahrer * [[Toni van Eyck]] as Hanni * [[Hermann Speelmans]] as Erwin Banz - Rennfahrer * [[Margarete Kupfer]] as Mutter Streblow * [[Jakob Tiedtke]] as Spengler - Fahrradhändler * [[Gustl Gstettenbaur]] as Gustl Spengler - sein Sohn * [[Ludwig Stössel]] * [[Flockina von Platen]] as Gina Paradies * [[Fritz Odemar]] as Lißmann - Prokurist * [[Harry Hardt]] as Manuel Rodriguet - Rennfahrer * [[Otto Wallburg]] as Gottfried Paradies * [[Fritz Kampers]] as Fritz Wagmüller - Willys Schrittmacher * [[Kurt Pulvermacher]] as Der kleine Paradies * [[Hans Zesch-Ballot]] as Hans Donath - Sportjournalist * [[Carl Balhaus]] * [[Trude Tandar]] * [[Ernst Behmer]] * [[Adolf Fischer (actor)|Adolf Fischer]] * [[Charlie Kracker]] * [[Emilie Kurz]] * [[Wera Liessem ]] * [[Ernst Morgan]] * [[Liselotte Rosen]] * [[Hans Hermann Schaufuß]] * [[Werner Stock]] * [[Toni Tetzlaff]] * [[Rolf Wenkhaus]] * [[Georg Kroschel]] * [[Kurt Thormann]] * [[Ewald Wenck]] == References == == Bibliography == * Waldman, Harry. ''Nazi Films in America, 1933-1942''. McFarland, 2008. == External links == * {{IMDb title|0023530}} {{Alfred Zeisler}} [[Category:1932 films]] [[Category:1930s comedy films]] [[Category:1930s sports films]] [[Category:German comedy films]] [[Category:German sports films]] [[Category:German films]] [[Category:Films of the Weimar Republic]] [[Category:German-language films]] [[Category:Films directed by Alfred Zeisler]] [[Category:Cycling films]] [[Category:Multilingual films]] [[Category:UFA films]] {{1930s-Germany-film-stub}} [[Category:German black-and-white films]]

{{Infobox stadium | name = Tempe Diablo Stadium | nickname = | logo_image = | logo_caption = | fullname = | image =[[File:T-Tempe Diablo Stadium2.JPG|250px]]
[[Image:Tempe Diablo Stadium.jpg|250px]] | caption = | former_names = | location = 2200 W. Alameda Drive
[[Tempe, Arizona|Tempe]], [[Arizona|AZ]] 85282 | coordinates = {{coord|33|24|2|N|111|58|11|W|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1969 | renovated = 2002 | expanded = | closed = | demolished = | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass | scoreboard = | estimated_cost = | suites = | architect = Populous (1993) | project_manager = | structural engineer = | services engineer = | general_contractor = | main_contractors = | capacity = 9,558 | record_attendance = | executive_suites = | dimensions = | acreage = | tenants = [[Seattle Pilots]]/[[Milwaukee Brewers]] (1969–1972)
[[Seattle Mariners]] (1977–1993)
[[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim]] (1993–present) }} '''Tempe Diablo Stadium''' is a [[baseball]] field located in [[Tempe, Arizona]]. It is the spring training home of the [[Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim]] and the home field for night games of the [[Arizona League]] [[Tempe Angels]]. It was the spring training home of the [[Seattle Pilots]] in 1969 and [[1970 Milwaukee Brewers season|1970]] (the Pilots moved to Milwaukee late in spring training of March 1970 and prior to the 1970 regular season), the [[Milwaukee Brewers]] in [[1971 Milwaukee Brewers season|1971]] and [[1972 Milwaukee Brewers season|1972]], and the [[Seattle Mariners]] from [[1977 Seattle Mariners season|1977]] through [[1977 Seattle Mariners season|1993]]; the Mariners now play at the [[Peoria Sports Complex]], with the [[San Diego Padres]]. The stadium was built in 1968 and holds 9,558 people. The stadium underwent an extensive $20 million renovation and was rededicated on Mar. 3, 2006. The renovation included the main stadium, the [[Major League Baseball|Major League]] Fields and the [[Minor League]] Complex on site. In return for the newly updated stadium, the Angels agreed to extend their spring training lease through Dec. 31, 2025. $12 million of the renovations were funded by the [[Arizona Sports and Tourism Authority]], a municipal corporation charged with funding renovations of [[Spring training#Cactus League (held in Arizona)|Cactus League]] stadiums throughout [[Maricopa County, Arizona|Maricopa County]]. Tempe Diablo Stadium can be seen from the [[Interstate 10 in Arizona|Maricopa Freeway]]. ==References== *[http://www.tempe.gov/diablo Tempe Diablo Stadium] at the City of Tempe web page {{Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim}} {{Milwaukee Brewers}} {{Seattle Mariners}} {{Stadiums of the Cactus League}} {{Arizona League Ballparks}} [[Category:Cactus League venues]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tempe, Arizona]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Arizona]] [[Category:Anaheim Angels spring training venues]] [[Category:Los Angeles Angels spring training venues]] [[Category:Los Angeles Angels of Anaheim spring training venues]] [[Category:Milwaukee Brewers spring training venues]] [[Category:Seattle Mariners spring training venues]] [[Category:1969 establishments in Arizona]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1969]] [[Category:Arizona League ballparks]] {{Arizona-baseball-venue-stub}}

{{Infobox film | name = Turbo Time | image = Turbo Time (1983 Film).jpg | alt = | caption = Italian theatrical release poster by [[Enzo Sciotti]] | film name = Turbo Time | director = [[James Davis (director)|James Davis]] | producer = [[Alessadro Fracassi]] | writer = [[Mario Morra]] | screenplay = [[Federico Urban]]
[[Lello Garinei]] | story = | based on = | starring = | narrator = | music = [[Daniele Patucchi]] | cinematography = [[Antonio Climati]] | editing = [[Mario Morra]] | production companies = Racing Pictures | distributor = Cinemedia | released = {{film date|1983|09|29|Italy}} | runtime = 91 minutes | country = [[Italy]] | language = | budget = | gross = }} '''''Turbo Time''''' is a 1983 Italian documentary film [[Film director|directed]] by [[Antonio Climati]] as [[James Davis (director)|James Davis]] and written by [[Mario Morra]] and .{{cite book|author1=Roberto Poppi|title=Dizionario del cinema italiano|publisher=Gremese, 1991, p. 311|language=IT|isbn=9788877424297}} ==Plot== Documentary about the world of car and motorcycle racing, accompanied by interviews with several champions of these sports. ==Release== The film was released in [[Italy]] on September 29, 1983{{cite web|url=http://archiviostorico.unita.it/cgi-bin/highlightPdf.cgi?t=ebook&file=/archivio/uni_1983_09/19830929_0015.pdf&query=%22turbo%20time%22|title=Cinema a Roma - prime visioni - Turbo Time|publisher=www.unita.it|accessdate=2016-09-10|language=IT}} ==See also== * [[List of Italian films of 1983]] ==Notes== {{reflist}} ==External links== * {{IMDb title|0211694}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Turbo Time}} [[Category:1983 films]] [[Category:Italian films]] [[Category:Italian documentary films]] [[Category:1980s documentary films]] [[Category:Formula One media]] [[Category:Motorcycle racing films]] [[Category:Documentaries about sports]] {{1980s-Italy-film-stub}}

revision.comment: find a source
revision.text:
[[File:Spyderco Warrior 2.jpg|thumb|Spyderco Warrior]] The '''Warrior knife''' is a large curved blade [[fighting knife]] with a serrated back edge that was first made by [[Al Mar Knives]] and Round Eye Knife and Tool (REKAT). Part of the knife's design is credited to martial arts instructor [[Michael Echanis]].
==Design== The Warrior knife was designed by custom knife maker, Vietnam combat veteran, and close combat instructor Bob Taylor and [[Hwarang-do]] expert Randy Wanner.<ref name="VanCook1999">{{cite book|last=VanCook|first=Jerry|title=Real world self-defense: a guide to staying alive in dangerous times|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wngbAQAAMAAJ|date=1 November 1999|publisher=Paladin Press|location=Boulder, Colorado|isbn=978-1-58160-044-5|pages=123, 188}}</ref> The blade is distinctive in that the entire rear portion of the blade has a serrated edge, that was added at the suggestion of Wanner's Hwarang-do student [[Michael D. Echanis]] and is the reason why the knife has the informal name "Echanis' Warrior".<ref name="Kertzman2011">{{cite book|last=Kertzman|first=Joe|title=Knives 2012: The World's Greatest Knife Book|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CQSAiPxe7bEC&pg=PA51|date=25 August 2011|publisher=Krause Publications|location=Iola, Wisconsin|isbn=1-4402-1691-6|page=51}}</ref><ref name ="WALK">{{cite book|last=Walker|first= Greg|title=Battle Blades: A Professional's Guide to Combat/Fighting Knives|location= Boulder, CO|publisher= Paladin Press| ISBN =0-87364-732-7 |year=1993|pages= 138-139}}</ref> Al Mar was an edged-weapons specialist in the U.S. Army Special Forces, a 5th degree black belt in Judo when he started Al Mar Knives in 1978 and began work on the famous and highly sought after "Warrior" knife. In his book, Battle Blades, Greg Walker[3] refers to the Al Mar Warrior as, "perhaps the ultimate in battle-blade design.
In addition to the rear serrations used for trapping an opponents' attacking limb, the knife is noted for having an extremely ergonomic handle for use in both the forward and reverse grip. The handle was designed by making a complex study of the human hand through a [[COBOL]] computer program and this design has gone on to influence other fighting knives such as [[Emerson Knives]]' CQC-8 model.<ref>{{Cite journal | last=Ewing| first=Dexter| title=Knives and Lights| journal=Blade Magazine |volume=31 |issue=3 | year=2004 | page=129}}</ref>
==Versions== The original version was made by Al Mar Knives and had either a polished or blackened blade with either a black or camouflage rubber handle.<ref name ="WALK"/>
Round Eye Knife and Tool made a smaller version known as the "Hobbit Warrior" and a folding version known as the "Pocket Hobbit".<ref>{{cite news|date=March 6, 2002 | last=Cheong|first= Sam|url=http://www.highbeam.com/doc/1P1-82634915.html|title=In search of the ultimate blade|newspaper=New Straits Times {{Subscription required|via=[[HighBeam Research]]}}}}</ref><ref name="VanCook1999"/>
[[Spyderco]] knives makes a version of this knife.<ref name="Kertzman2011"/><ref name="Eckstine2012">{{cite book|last=Eckstine|first=Roger|title=Shooter's Bible Guide to Knives: A Complete Guide to Hunting Knives, Survival Knives, Folding Knives, Skinning Knives, Sharpeners, and More|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=8iCtTOM1_G8C&pg=PT33|date=1 April 2012|publisher=Skyhorse Publishing Inc.|isbn=978-1-62087-309-0|page=33}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}} {{Knives}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Warrior knife}} [[Category:Military knives]] [[Category:Mechanical hand tools]] [[Category:Camping equipment]] [[Category:Goods manufactured in the United States]]
